query: Who did John Stevens Henslow marry, and what was her familial connection to Leonard Jenyns?
reference_contexts:
['== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought.


== Selected publications ==
Henslow, John Stevens (1822). "Geological Description of Anglesea". Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society. 1: 359–452.
Henslow, John Stevens. (1823). A Syllabus of a Course of Lectures on Mineralogy. Deighton (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00201-1)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1829; 2nd ed. 1835). A Catalogue of British Plants.
Henslow, John Stevens. (1835). The Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany. Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown & Green (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00186-1)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1846). The Teaching of Science in Cambridge. Metcalfe and Palmer (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00200-4)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1856). A Dictionary of Botanical Terms. Groombridge (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00131-1)
Henslow, John Stevens, and Skepper, E. (1866). Flora of Suffolk


== References ==

== Sources ==

Complete Correspondence of John Stevens Henslow Searchable full texts of over 1000 letters to and from Henslow
Adam Sedgwick FRS (; 22 March 1785 – 27 January 1873) was a British geologist and Anglican priest, one of the founders of modern geology.  He proposed the Cambrian and Devonian period of the geological timescale. Based on work which he did on Welsh rock strata, he proposed the Cambrian period in 1835, in a joint publication in which Roderick Murchison also proposed the Silurian period.  Later in 1840, to resolve what later became known as the Great Devonian Controversy about rocks near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods, he and Murchison proposed the Devonian period.
Though he had guided the young Charles Darwin in his early study of geology and continued to be on friendly terms, Sedgwick was an opponent of Darwin's theory of evolution by means of natural selection.
He strongly opposed the admission of women to the University of Cambridge, in one conversation describing aspiring female students as "nasty forward minxes."']
reference_answer: John Stevens Henslow married Harriet Jenyns on December 16, 1823. Harriet was the daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and the sister of Leonard Jenyns. This establishes a familial connection between Harriet and Leonard Jenyns as siblings.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick made a significant contribution to the geological timescale by proposing the Cambrian period in 1835. This proposal was part of a joint publication with Roderick Murchison, who also proposed the Silurian period at that time. Later, in 1840, Sedgwick and Murchison addressed what became known as the Great Devonian Controversy by proposing the Devonian period to resolve debates about rock strata near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods.

Regarding his views on Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, Adam Sedgwick was an opponent. Although he had guided Darwin in his early study of geology and maintained a friendly relationship with him, Sedgwick did not support Darwin's theory of evolution by means of natural selection. This difference in scientific opinion highlights the divergence between Sedgwick's traditional views on geology and biology and Darwin's revolutionary ideas about evolution.

Additionally, it is noted that Sedgwick opposed the admission of women to the University of Cambridge, reflecting his conservative stance on social issues of his time.

John Stevens Henslow played a significant role in academia as a professor of botany. He served as the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany, contributing to the field through both teaching and research.

One of his notable publications is "The Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany," originally published in 1835. query: What academic disciplines did Sedgwick study at Trinity College, Cambridge, and what notable achievement did he earn upon obtaining his BA?
reference_contexts:
['== Life and career ==
Sedgwick was born in Dent, Yorkshire, the third child of an Anglican vicar. He was educated at Sedbergh School and Trinity College, Cambridge.
He studied mathematics and theology, and obtained his BA (5th Wrangler) from the University of Cambridge in 1808 and his MA in 1811. On 20 July 1817 he was ordained a deacon, then a year later he was ordained as a priest. His academic mentors at Cambridge were Thomas Jones and John Dawson. He became a Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge and Woodwardian Professor of Geology at Cambridge from 1818, holding the chair until his death in 1873. His biography in the Cambridge Alumni database says that upon his acceptance of the position, Sedgwick had no working knowledge of geology. An 1851 portrait of Sedgwick by William Boxall hangs in Trinity's collection.
Sedgwick studied the geology of the British Isles and Europe. He founded the system for the classification of Cambrian rocks and with Roderick Murchison worked out the order of the Carboniferous and underlying Devonian strata. These studies were mostly carried out in the 1830s. The investigations into the Devonian meant that Sedgwick was involved with Murchison in a vigorous debate with Henry De la Beche, in what became known as the great Devonian controversy.
He also employed John William Salter for a short time in arranging the fossils in the Woodwardian Museum at Cambridge, and whom accompanied the professor on several geological expeditions (1842–1845) into Wales. John Ruthven, with whom Sedgwick has a room at Kendal museum co-named after him, also frequently accompanied Sedgwick in Wales and beyond.
Sedgwick investigated the phenomena of metamorphism and concretion, and was the first to distinguish clearly between stratification, jointing, and slaty cleavage. He was elected to Fellow of the Royal Society on 1 February 1821. In 1844, he was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was president of the Geological Society of London.


== Geological views and evolution ==

The Church of England, by no means a fundamentalist or evangelical church, encloses a wide range of beliefs. During Sedgwick's life there developed something of a chasm between the conservative high church believers and the liberal wing. After simmering for some years, the publication of Essays and Reviews by liberal churchmen in 1860 pinpointed the differences. In all this, Sedgwick, whose science and faith were intertwined in a natural theology, was definitely on the conservative side, and extremely outspoken about it. He told the February 1830 meeting of the Geological Society of London:

No opinion can be heretical, but that which is not true.... Conflicting falsehoods we can comprehend; but truths can never war against each other. I affirm, therefore, that we have nothing to fear from the results of our enquiries, provided they be followed in the laborious but secure road of honest induction. In this way we may rest assured that we shall never arrive at conclusions opposed to any truth, either physical or moral, from whatever source that truth may be derived ...
As a geologist in the mid-1820s he supported William Buckland's interpretation of certain superficial deposits, particularly loose rocks and gravel, as "diluvium" relating to worldwide floods, and in 1825 he published two papers identifying these as due to a "great irregular inundation" from the "waters of a general deluge", Noah's flood. Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic. In early 1827, after spending several weeks in Paris, he visited geological features in the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison. He later wrote "If I have been converted in part from the diluvian theory...it was...by my own gradual improved experience, and by communicating with those about me. Perhaps I may date my change of mind (at least in part) from our journey in the Highlands, where there are so many indications of local diluvial operations.... Humboldt ridiculed [the doctrine] beyond measure when I met him in Paris. Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral.']
reference_answer:
Sedgwick studied mathematics and theology at Trinity College, Cambridge. Upon obtaining his Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1808, he achieved the notable distinction of being ranked as the fifth Wrangler, which indicates a high level of achievement in the mathematical tripos examination.

**Relevant Context:**
- Sedgwick's education included mathematics and theology.
- He obtained his BA from the University of Cambridge in 1808 with the rank of 5th Wrangler.

He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick made significant contributions to the field of geology during his career. Despite initially having no working knowledge of geology when he became Woodwardian Professor of Geology at Cambridge, he went on to become a prominent figure in geological studies.

One of Sedgwick's major achievements was founding the system for classifying Cambrian rocks. He collaborated closely with Roderick Murchison, another influential geologist, to work out the order of Carboniferous and underlying Devonian strata during the 1830s. Their collaborative efforts were crucial in advancing the understanding of geological time scales and rock formations.

Sedgwick and Murchison's work led them into a significant scientific debate known as the great Devonian controversy. This controversy involved vigorous discussions with Henry De la Beche over the classification and interpretation of certain strata, particularly those related to the Devonian period. The debate highlighted differing views on geological processes and the history of Earth's formations.

In addition to his work with Murchison, Sedgwick made important contributions by investigating phenomena such as metamorphism and concretion. He was notably the first to clearly distinguish between stratification, jointing, and slaty cleavage—key concepts in understanding rock structures.

Sedgwick also played a role in mentoring younger geologists, employing individuals like John William Salter to arrange fossils at the Woodwardian Museum and accompanying him on geological expeditions. His leadership extended beyond research as he served as president of the Geological Society of London and was recognized by various scientific societies for his contributions.

Overall, Sedgwick's work laid foundational elements in stratigraphy and paleontology, influencing future generations of geologists through both his discoveries and his mentorship.

['== Life and career ==

reference_answer:
Sedgwick's views on evolution and divine creation were closely aligned with his conservative stance within the Church of England. During his lifetime, there was a growing divide between conservative high church believers and more liberal factions within the church. Sedgwick was firmly positioned on the conservative side, intertwining his scientific work with natural theology—a belief that nature reflects God's design.

Sedgwick believed in the idea that species originated through successive Divine creative acts over history, rather than through a process of development or evolution that denied direct divine intervention. This perspective reflected his opposition to materialistic and amoral interpretations of life’s origins, which he associated with evolutionary theories that did not involve God's active role.

His outspoken nature on these matters was evident in his statements at the Geological Society of London, where he emphasized that truths could never conflict with each other, suggesting a harmony between scientific findings and religious beliefs. Sedgwick's rejection of materialistic explanations for geological phenomena further underscored his commitment to a worldview that upheld divine creation as central.

Overall, Sedgwick’s views on evolution and divine creation mirrored the conservative theological stance within the Church of England during his time, emphasizing faith in God's direct involvement in the natural world.

query: How did Sedgwick's views on geology and divine creation influence his response to Charles Lyell's "Principles of Geology" and what was his stance on Buckland's theory by February 18, 1831?
reference_contexts:
['Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.  However, Sedgwick never accepted the case for evolution made in On the Origin of Species in 1859 any more than he did that in  Vestiges in 1844.  In response to receiving and reading Darwin's book, he wrote to Darwin saying:

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure.']
reference_answer:
Sedgwick's views on geology were deeply intertwined with his belief in Divine creation. He held that species originated through a succession of divine acts throughout history, which influenced his response to Charles Lyell's "Principles of Geology." Lyell's work promoted uniformitarianism, the idea that geological processes observed today have always operated in the same manner over time. Sedgwick opposed this view because it implied naturalistic explanations for Earth's features without direct divine intervention, which he saw as materialistic and amoral.

By February 18, 1831, when Sedgwick retired from the Presidency of the Geological Society, he recanted his former belief in William Buckland's theory. Buckland had proposed that a great flood explained many geological formations, aligning more closely with Sedgwick's views on divine intervention. However, Sedgwick eventually moved away from this specific flood-based explanation, likely due to increasing evidence supporting uniformitarianism and the scientific community's shift towards it.

Despite his initial opposition to Lyell's ideas, Sedgwick supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen who opposed such progress as unscriptural. His stance reflects a complex relationship with both science and religion, advocating for geological study while maintaining that moral truths were distinct from physical ones.

query: In what ways did Sedgwick criticize the scriptural geologists in 1830 and 1834, and how did Henry Cole respond to Sedgwick's ideas in 1834?
reference_contexts:
['Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.  However, Sedgwick never accepted the case for evolution made in On the Origin of Species in 1859 any more than he did that in  Vestiges in 1844.  In response to receiving and reading Darwin's book, he wrote to Darwin saying:

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure.']
reference_answer:
In 1830, Adam Sedgwick criticized scriptural geologists by describing their conclusions as "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions," which he believed had brought shame upon sober philosophy and even disrupted social harmony. By 1834, his criticism intensified; he accused them of committing a "folly and SIN" by dogmatizing against plain sense and writing what he considered to be "mischievous nonsense." Sedgwick argued that scriptural geologists were unable or unwilling to accept truth due to their perceived ignorance and dishonesty. He characterized their approach as showing "bigotry and ignorance," particularly regarding nature's laws and natural phenomena.

In response, Henry Cole addressed Sedgwick's ideas in 1834 through a lengthy 136-page letter titled "Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation." Cole labeled Sedgwick’s views as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," accusing them of being "scripture-defying" and "revelation-subverting." He described Sedgwick's theories as consisting of "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which he deemed "impious and infidel."

This exchange highlights the tension between scientific inquiry and religious beliefs during that period, with both parties accusing each other of undermining their respective positions.

query: Describe Sedgwick's reaction to Robert Chambers' "Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation" and his subsequent actions regarding the book's publication and its implications for science and religion.

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick had a strongly negative reaction to Robert Chambers' "Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation." Initially, like many eminent scientists of his time, he ignored the book upon its release in October 1844. However, as discussions about its content persisted, Sedgwick decided to read it carefully and subsequently made a severe critique.

In July 1845, Sedgwick published a scathing review in the Edinburgh Review. He described "Vestiges" as presenting a deceptive philosophy that lured readers into accepting false ideas, likening it to the biblical story of the serpent offering forbidden fruit. Sedgwick believed that accepting the arguments in "Vestiges" would lead people away from religious faith and divine favor.

Sedgwick's disapproval extended beyond his review; he expressed his disdain for the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, where he lamented its implications. He argued that if the ideas in "Vestiges" were true, it would render many aspects of human endeavor meaningless or misguided—such as scientific labor, religious belief, morality, and social justice efforts.

Furthermore, Sedgwick included an extensive critique of "Vestiges" and theories of development in general in a long preface to the 5th edition of his work, "Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge," published in 1850. His actions reflect his commitment to defending traditional religious views against what he saw as materialistic and amoral scientific theories that challenged divine creation.

Overall, Sedgwick's reaction to "Vestiges" was one of strong opposition, both intellectually and emotionally, due to its perceived threat to established religious beliefs and moral truths.

query: How did Adam Sedgwick's reaction to Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" reflect his views on scientific methodology and causation?
reference_contexts:
['The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.  However, Sedgwick never accepted the case for evolution made in On the Origin of Species in 1859 any more than he did that in  Vestiges in 1844.  In response to receiving and reading Darwin's book, he wrote to Darwin saying:

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure. Parts of it I admired greatly; parts I laughed at till my sides were almost sore; other parts I read with absolute sorrow; because I think them utterly false & grievously mischievous – You have deserted—after a start in that tram-road of all solid physical truth—the true method of induction—& started up a machinery as wild I think as Bishop Wilkins's locomotive that was to sail with us to the Moon. Many of your wide conclusions are based upon assumptions which can neither be proved nor disproved. Why then express them in the language & arrangements of philosophical induction?
Sedgwick regarded natural selection as

but a secondary consequence of supposed, or known, primary facts. Development is a better word because more close to the cause of the fact. For you do not deny causation. I call (in the abstract) causation the will of God: & I can prove that He acts for the good of His creatures. He also acts by laws which we can study &  comprehend—Acting by law, & under what is called final cause, comprehends, I think, your whole principle ...
He emphasised his distinction between the moral and physical aspects of life, "There is a moral or metaphysical part of nature as well as a physical. A man who denies this is deep in the mire of folly". If humanity broke this distinction it "would suffer a damage that might brutalize it—& sink the human race into a lower grade of degradation than any into which it has fallen since its written records tell us of its history".
In a letter to another correspondent, Sedgwick was even harsher on Darwin's book, calling it "utterly false" and writing that "It repudiates all reasoning from final causes; and seems to shut the door on any view (however feeble) of the God of Nature as manifested in His works. From first to last it is a dish of rank materialism cleverly cooked and served up".
Despite this difference of opinion, the two men remained friendly until Sedgwick's death. In contrast to Sedgwick, liberal church members (who included biologists such as George Rolleston, William Henry Flower and William Kitchen Parker) were usually comfortable with evolution.


== Links and opposition to slavery ==
As a co-trustee of the will of Ann Sill, an owner of slaves in plantations in Jamaica, in 1835 Sedgwick was awarded half of £3,783 in compensation for 174 slaves, following the abolition of slavery by the British government. Sedgwick is listed in the University College London database, Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave Ownership, as being an awardee in receipt of £3,783 1s 8d on 8 February 1836 for "174 Enslaved". He was one of 46,000 people paid compensation during the abolition of slavery in the United Kingdom. A liberal Whig in politics, Sedgwick had long been a passionate supporter of abolition. In a letter to Bishop Wilberforce, dated July 16, 1848, Sedgwick wrote of signing a petition against the slave trade while he was a child—the first "political act of [his] life"—after his father had shown him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery".']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's reaction to Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" reflects his strong adherence to traditional scientific methodologies and his belief in a divine framework for understanding natural phenomena. In his correspondence with Darwin, Sedgwick criticized the book for abandoning what he considered the "true method of induction," which involves deriving general principles from specific observations. He viewed Darwin's approach as speculative, likening it to an impractical invention by Bishop Wilkins meant to travel to the Moon.

Sedgwick believed that many of Darwin's conclusions were based on assumptions that could neither be proven nor disproven and thus should not be presented with the authority of philosophical induction. This indicates his preference for empirical evidence and logical reasoning in scientific inquiry, as opposed to what he saw as speculative theories without solid grounding.

Furthermore, Sedgwick emphasized causation as a divine principle, referring to it abstractly as "the will of God." He argued that natural laws, which could be studied and understood, were manifestations of this divine will acting for the good of creation. This perspective underscores his belief in a purposeful universe governed by final causes or teleology, contrasting with Darwin's materialistic explanation of evolution through natural selection.

Sedgwick also highlighted the distinction between moral/metaphysical aspects and physical aspects of nature, suggesting that denying this separation could lead to a degradation of humanity. His reaction reflects an integration of scientific inquiry with theological and philosophical considerations, emphasizing a worldview where science and religion coexist harmoniously.

Overall, Sedgwick's response to Darwin's work illustrates his commitment to traditional scientific methods, his belief in divine causation, and his concern for maintaining the moral dimensions of human understanding within the natural sciences.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's reconciliation of his religious beliefs with his stance on evolution is evident in his correspondence with Charles Darwin. Despite rejecting the theory of natural selection as presented in "On the Origin of Species," Sedgwick maintained a distinction between moral and physical aspects of life, emphasizing that there was a "moral or metaphysical part of nature" alongside the physical. He believed that causation could be attributed to divine will, which he referred to as "the will of God." This perspective allowed him to view natural laws as manifestations of God's actions for the good of His creatures.

Sedgwick criticized Darwin's work for what he perceived as its materialistic approach and rejection of reasoning from final causes. He argued that Darwin's theory seemed to exclude any consideration of a divine presence in nature, which Sedgwick found problematic. However, despite these criticisms, Sedgwick did not entirely dismiss the concept of development or change within species; rather, he preferred to frame it as "development" rather than evolution by natural selection.

Sedgwick's ability to maintain his religious beliefs while engaging with evolutionary ideas is reflected in his view that God acts through comprehensible laws. This allowed him to appreciate aspects of scientific inquiry without fully embracing Darwin's conclusions. His correspondence shows a nuanced position where he could critique specific scientific theories while still upholding his broader theological views, thus maintaining a personal and professional relationship with Darwin despite their differences.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick was involved in both receiving compensation related to slavery and actively opposing it. As a co-trustee of Ann Sill's will, he received half of £3,783 as compensation for 174 enslaved individuals following the abolition of slavery by the British government in 1835. This payment was made on February 8, 1836, reflecting his status among the approximately 46,000 people who were compensated during this period.

Despite receiving such compensation, Sedgwick was a passionate supporter of abolition and held liberal Whig political views. He had long opposed slavery, as evidenced by his early involvement in anti-slavery activities. In a letter to Bishop Wilberforce dated July 16, 1848, Sedgwick recounted signing an anti-slave trade petition during his childhood after being shown "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery" by his father. This act was described as the first political action of his life, highlighting his early and enduring commitment to opposing the slave trade.

Sedgwick's dual role as both a recipient of compensation for slaves and an advocate against slavery illustrates the complex historical context in which individuals navigated their personal beliefs and societal structures during this period.

query: In what year was the Sedgwick Museum, established in honor of Adam Sedgwick, officially opened?
reference_contexts:
['== Legacy ==

The Sedgwick Club, the oldest student-run geological society in the world, was set up in honour of him in 1880.
On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hitherto the geological collections had been placed in the Woodwardian Museum in Cockerell's Building. Through the energy of Professor T. McK. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.
In 1865, the University of Cambridge received from A. A. Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.


== Notes ==


== References ==
Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Sedgwick, Adam" . Encyclopædia Britannica. Vol. 24 (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp. 557–558.
J.W. Clark and T.M. Hughes, The Life and Letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, Cambridge University Press, 1890, vols. 1–2. (Reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-1-108-01831-9)
Dictionary of Scientific Biography, Charles Scribner's Sons: 1970–1990; vol. 12, pp. 275–279.
A Biographical Dictionary of Scientists, Williams, T. I., Ed., Wiley, 1969, pp. 467–468.
Isaac Asimov, I. Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology (2nd Ed.), Doubleday: 1982, p. 299.
Quart. J. Geol. Soc., 1873, 29, pp. xxx–xxxix.
Bonney, Thomas George (1889). "Sedgwick, Adam" . In Stephen, Leslie (ed.). Dictionary of National Biography. Vol. 17. London: Smith, Elder & Co. pp. 179–182.
"Adam Sedgwick – Geologist and Dalesman" Colin Speakman Broad Oak Press 1982.
"Adam Sedgwick's Dent"  A facsimile reprint of 'A Memorial by the Trustees of Cowgill Chapel (1868) and 'Supplement to the Memorial (1870) by Adam Sedgwick with introduction by David Boulton Hollett, Sedbergh and David Boulton Dent 1984.
"A Discourse on the Studies of the University" Adam Sedgwick The Victorian Library, Leicester University Press 1969
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Herbert, Sandra (1991), "Charles Darwin as a prospective geological author", British Journal for the History of Science, vol. 24, no. 2, pp. 159–192, doi:10.1017/s0007087400027060, S2CID 143748414, archived from the original on 8 February 2009, retrieved 24 January 2009
Secord, James A. (2000), Victorian Sensation: the extraordinary publication, reception, and secret authorship of Vestiges of the natural history of creation, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, ISBN 0-226-74411-6']
reference_answer: The Sedgwick Museum, established in honor of Adam Sedgwick, was officially opened in the year 1903. This information is provided in the context where it mentions that through the efforts of Professor T. McK. Hughes, the new building termed the Sedgwick Museum was completed and opened in 1903.

Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.

The Sedgwick Club, the oldest student-run geological society in the world, was set up in honour of him in 1880.
On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.

reference_answer: Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, holds significant importance as part of the legacy of Adam Sedgwick, a renowned geologist and one of the founders of modern geology. The mountain was officially named after him in 1951, serving as a tribute to his contributions to the field of geology. This naming honors Sedgwick's influence and achievements, including his role in establishing geological societies such as the Sedgwick Club and his involvement with the University of Cambridge through initiatives like the Sedgwick Prize for geological studies. The mountain stands as a geographical marker that commemorates Sedgwick's enduring impact on geology and education.

query: What was the original duration planned for the Beagle expedition, and how long did it actually last? Explain the significance of this extended period for Darwin's work.
reference_contexts:
['== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge
Works by or about Adam Sedgwick at the Internet Archive
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.2 by J.W.Clark, 1890
Obituary in: "Obituary" . Popular Science Monthly. Vol. 2. April 1873.
The Voyage of the Beagle is the title most commonly given to the book written by Charles Darwin and published in 1839 as his Journal and Remarks, bringing him considerable fame and respect. This was the third volume of The Narrative of the Voyages of H.M. Ships Adventure and Beagle, the other volumes of which were written or edited by the commanders of the ships. Journal and Remarks covers Darwin's part in the second survey expedition of the ship HMS Beagle. Due to the popularity of Darwin's account, the publisher reissued it later in 1839 as Darwin's Journal of Researches, and the revised second edition published in 1845 used this title. A republication of the book in 1905 introduced the title The Voyage of the "Beagle", by which it is now best known.

Beagle sailed from Plymouth Sound on 27 December 1831 under the command of Captain Robert FitzRoy. While the expedition was originally planned to last two years, it lasted almost five—Beagle did not return until 2 October 1836. Darwin spent most of this time exploring on land (three years and three months on land; 18 months at sea). The book is a vivid travel memoir as well as a detailed scientific field journal covering biology, geology, and anthropology that demonstrates Darwin's keen powers of observation, written at a time when Western Europeans were exploring and charting the whole world. Although Darwin revisited some areas during the expedition, for clarity the chapters of the book are ordered by reference to places and locations rather than by date.
Darwin's notes made during the voyage include comments hinting at his changing views on the fixity of species. On his return, he wrote the book based on these notes, at a time when he was first developing his theories of evolution through common descent and natural selection. The book includes some suggestions of his ideas, particularly in the second edition of 1845.


== Context ==
In May 1826 two ships left Plymouth to survey the southern coasts of South America. The senior officer of the expedition was Phillip Parker King, Commander and Surveyor of HMS Adventure, and under his orders Pringle Stokes was Commander and Surveyor of HMS Beagle. In August 1828 Stokes died after shooting himself. In December Robert FitzRoy was given command of the ship and continued the survey. In January 1830 FitzRoy noted in his journal the need for expertise in mineralogy or geology, on a future expedition he would "endeavour to carry out a person qualified to examine the land; while the officers, and myself, would attend to hydrography." Both ships returned to Plymouth in August 1830. King was in poor health, and retired from the Navy (he moved back to his home in Australia in 1832).
In August 1831, while Beagle was being readied, FitzRoy's offer of a place for a self-funded naturalist was raised with University of Cambridge professors. Henslow passed it on to Darwin who was well qualified and, enthused by reading Humboldt's Personal Narrative, was on a short study tour with geologist Adam Sedgwick in preparation for a planned visit with friends to Tenerife. Darwin read the letters when he got home, and was eager to join the voyage.']
reference_answer:
The original duration planned for the Beagle expedition was two years. However, the voyage lasted almost five years, with the ship returning to Plymouth on October 2, 1836.

The extended period of the Beagle expedition had significant implications for Charles Darwin's work and his development of evolutionary theory:

1. **Extended Observation Time**: The additional time allowed Darwin more opportunities to observe a wide variety of geological formations, fossils, and living organisms across different continents and islands. This extensive fieldwork was crucial in shaping his ideas about natural selection and evolution.

2. **Diverse Environments**: During the extended voyage, Darwin visited numerous locations, including South America, the Galápagos Islands, Australia, and New Zealand. Each environment provided unique insights into biodiversity and geological processes, contributing to his understanding of species adaptation and variation.

3. **Development of Theories**: The extra time enabled Darwin to gather a vast amount of data and make detailed observations that were critical in formulating his theories on evolution through common descent and natural selection. His notes from the voyage included early hints at these ideas, which he later expanded upon in his seminal work, "On the Origin of Species."

4. **Scientific Collaboration**: The extended duration allowed Darwin to correspond with other scientists and experts, such as Adam Sedgwick, who influenced his thinking and provided guidance on geological matters.

Overall, the longer-than-expected voyage was instrumental in providing Darwin with the empirical evidence needed to develop his groundbreaking theories on evolution.

query: Describe the role of Adam Sedgwick in relation to Charles Darwin before the voyage of HMS Beagle began. How might their relationship have influenced Darwin’s decision to join the expedition?

['== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge
Works by or about Adam Sedgwick at the Internet Archive
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick played a significant role as an academic mentor and influence on Charles Darwin prior to the voyage of HMS Beagle. As a professor at the University of Cambridge, Sedgwick was well-regarded in the field of geology. In preparation for his planned visit with friends to Tenerife, Darwin embarked on a short study tour with Sedgwick. This experience likely provided Darwin with valuable insights and inspiration, particularly given Sedgwick's expertise in geology.

Sedgwick's influence is evident in Darwin’s enthusiasm for natural sciences, which was further ignited by reading Alexander von Humboldt's "Personal Narrative." When the opportunity arose for a self-funded naturalist to join the Beagle expedition, it was through the academic network at Cambridge that this offer reached Darwin. Sedgwick, along with Professor Henslow, played a part in passing on FitzRoy’s proposal to Darwin.

The relationship between Sedgwick and Darwin likely had a significant impact on Darwin's decision to join the expedition. Sedgwick's mentorship would have instilled confidence in Darwin's abilities as a naturalist and geologist, encouraging him to seize this unique opportunity for exploration and scientific discovery. This academic backing, combined with his own burgeoning interest in natural history, made the prospect of joining the Beagle both appealing and professionally advantageous for Darwin.

query: Discuss the changes made between the first and second editions of "The Voyage of the Beagle" by Charles Darwin, particularly focusing on how these revisions reflect his evolving scientific ideas.
reference_contexts:
['== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge
Works by or about Adam Sedgwick at the Internet Archive
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.2 by J.W.Clark, 1890
Obituary in: "Obituary" . Popular Science Monthly. Vol. 2. April 1873.
The Voyage of the Beagle is the title most commonly given to the book written by Charles Darwin and published in 1839 as his Journal and Remarks, bringing him considerable fame and respect. == Context ==

Both ships returned to Plymouth in August 1830. King was in poor health, and retired from the Navy (he moved back to his home in Australia in 1832).
In August 1831, while Beagle was being readied, FitzRoy's offer of a place for a self-funded naturalist was raised with University of Cambridge professors. Henslow passed it on to Darwin who was well qualified and, enthused by reading Humboldt's Personal Narrative, was on a short study tour with geologist Adam Sedgwick in preparation for a planned visit with friends to Tenerife. Darwin read the letters when he got home, and was eager to join the voyage.']
reference_answer:
Between the first edition of "Journal and Remarks," published in 1839 as part of "The Narrative of the Voyages of H.M. Ships Adventure and Beagle," and its second edition, titled "Darwin's Journal of Researches" in 1845, several significant changes were made that reflect Charles Darwin's evolving scientific ideas.

1. **Title Change**: The first edition was published under a more formal title, "Journal and Remarks." By the time of the second edition, it had been rebranded as "Darwin's Journal of Researches," emphasizing Darwin’s personal contributions and observations during the voyage. This change reflects an increased recognition of Darwin's role in scientific exploration.

2. **Content Revisions**: The second edition included revisions that subtly introduced Darwin's emerging ideas on evolution. While the first edition primarily served as a travel memoir with detailed scientific observations, the 1845 version incorporated more reflections on natural history and geology, hinting at his developing theories of species change over time.

3. **Introduction of Evolutionary Ideas**: In the second edition, Darwin began to include comments that suggested his shifting views on the fixity of species. These hints were not explicit declarations but rather observations and questions about the diversity of life forms he encountered, which laid the groundwork for his later theories of evolution through natural selection.

4. **Increased Emphasis on Scientific Observations**: The revisions in the second edition placed greater emphasis on Darwin's scientific observations and interpretations. This shift reflects his growing confidence in his hypotheses regarding geological processes and biological diversity, influenced by his experiences during the voyage.

5. **Personal Reflections**: The 1845 edition also included more personal reflections and insights into Darwin’s thought process as he began to formulate ideas that would later culminate in "On the Origin of Species." These additions provided readers with a glimpse into how his observations were leading him towards revolutionary scientific conclusions.

Overall, the changes between the first and second editions of "The Voyage of the Beagle" illustrate Darwin's transition from a naturalist documenting his findings to a scientist contemplating broader implications about life on Earth. The revisions reflect his evolving understanding of nature and foreshadow the development of his groundbreaking theories on evolution.

query: What feedback did Caroline provide about Darwin's early diary entries, and how did it reflect her perception of his writing style influenced by Humboldt?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. He then wrote up his diary entries from these notes or from memory, sometimes several weeks after the event.
Pages 1 and 2, dated 16 December 1831, outline events from Darwin arriving home on 29 August to his arrival at Devonport on 24 October. From page 3 onwards he adopts a consistent layout, with month, the year and place in a heading at the top, page number in a top corner, and the day of the month in the margin at each entry. After delays and false starts due to weather, they set off on 27 December. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".
In April, a month after reaching South America, he wrote to his sister Caroline that he was struggling to write letters, partly due to "writing everything in my journal". A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". He invited criticisms. In reply, his sister Catherine praised his "interesting and entertaining" descriptions,  "Susan read the Journal aloud to Papa, who was interested, and liked it very much". His Wedgwood relatives had asked to see it at Maer Hall. Darwin left that "entirely in your hands.— I suspect the first part is abominaly childish, if so do not send it to Maer.— Also, do not send it by the Coach, (it may appear ridiculous to you) but I would as soon loose a piece of my memory as it.— I feel it is of such consequence to my preserving a just recollection of the different places we visit."
By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
Caroline provided specific feedback on Charles Darwin's early diary entries. She noted that Darwin had likely been influenced by reading Alexander von Humboldt, as evidenced by the adoption of Humboldt's phraseology in his writing. Caroline observed that Darwin occasionally used "flowery French expressions" similar to those found in Humboldt's work, which contrasted with Darwin's own simpler and more straightforward style. She pointed out that this influence might have led Darwin to unconsciously incorporate Humboldt's poetic language into his diary entries.

Despite these observations about the stylistic influence, Caroline expressed overall appreciation for Darwin's writing. She mentioned that she found "the greatest part" of the journal exceedingly likable and could find no fault with it. This feedback reflects her perception that while Darwin's style had been influenced by Humboldt, making it occasionally more ornate than his usual straightforward manner, the content remained engaging and enjoyable to read.

Caroline's comments suggest an awareness of how external influences can shape one's writing style, yet she also recognized the inherent value in Darwin's observations and descriptions. Her feedback was constructive, acknowledging both the stylistic influence and the overall quality of the diary entries.

query: In April 1836, what proposal did Captain FitzRoy make to Darwin regarding the publication of their voyage accounts, and what was Darwin’s response?

['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===

reference_answer:
In April 1836, Captain FitzRoy proposed to Charles Darwin that they collaborate on publishing an account of their voyage. Specifically, FitzRoy suggested that he would have control over arranging and incorporating Darwin's journal entries into the publication alongside his own narrative. He asked Darwin if he was willing to join him in this endeavor, indicating that he found the "chit-chat details" of Darwin's journal potentially valuable for inclusion.

Darwin responded positively to FitzRoy's proposal. He expressed his willingness to participate in publishing their accounts together, provided that FitzRoy deemed the materials from Darwin's journal worth including. This response shows Darwin's readiness to collaborate and contribute to a joint publication with FitzRoy, respecting the captain's discretion over how the material would be used.

query: What plan did FitzRoy propose for dividing the work and profits from the volumes based on materials collected during their voyages, and how did Darwin respond to this proposal?
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
FitzRoy proposed a collaborative plan where they would each write separate volumes based on the materials collected during their voyages. Specifically, one volume was suggested for King, another for Darwin, and a third for FitzRoy himself. The profits from these publications were to be divided equally into three portions among them.

Darwin agreed with this proposal and began working on his assigned volume. He planned to write a "kind of journal of a naturalist," focusing not strictly on chronological order but rather on the geographical positioning of their observations. Darwin intended for his volume to include extensive details about animal habits, geology sketches, descriptions of the country's appearance, and personal anecdotes. Additionally, he planned to later produce a detailed account of the geology and some zoological papers. This plan indicated that Darwin had significant work ahead for the next year or two, during which time he would not take any holidays.

reference_answer:
Charles Darwin intended for his volume in the planned series of publications to be structured as a "kind of journal of a naturalist." Unlike a traditional chronological account, he aimed to organize the content based on the order of position rather than strictly following the sequence of events. This approach allowed him to focus more on thematic elements and specific observations.

The content Darwin planned for his volume included several key components:

1. **Habits of Animals**: A significant portion of the volume was dedicated to exploring the behaviors and characteristics of various animals encountered during the voyage.

2. **Geology**: He intended to provide sketches and insights into the geological aspects observed, offering a glimpse into the earth's structure and composition in different regions visited.

3. **Appearance of the Country**: Descriptions of the landscapes and physical features of the places explored were also planned to be included, giving readers a vivid sense of the environments encountered.

4. **Personal Details**: Darwin aimed to incorporate personal anecdotes and reflections, adding depth and context to his scientific observations.

Overall, Darwin's volume was designed as a comprehensive "hodge-podge" that combined natural history with personal narrative, providing a richly detailed account of his experiences and findings during the voyage. This structure allowed him to delve deeply into specific topics while maintaining an engaging and varied narrative style.

query: What feedback did Caroline provide about Darwin's early diary entries, and how did it reflect her perception of his writing style?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. He then wrote up his diary entries from these notes or from memory, sometimes several weeks after the event.
Pages 1 and 2, dated 16 December 1831, outline events from Darwin arriving home on 29 August to his arrival at Devonport on 24 October. From page 3 onwards he adopts a consistent layout, with month, the year and place in a heading at the top, page number in a top corner, and the day of the month in the margin at each entry. After delays and false starts due to weather, they set off on 27 December. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".
In April, a month after reaching South America, he wrote to his sister Caroline that he was struggling to write letters, partly due to "writing everything in my journal". A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". He invited criticisms. In reply, his sister Catherine praised his "interesting and entertaining" descriptions,  "Susan read the Journal aloud to Papa, who was interested, and liked it very much". His Wedgwood relatives had asked to see it at Maer Hall. Darwin left that "entirely in your hands.— I suspect the first part is abominaly childish, if so do not send it to Maer.— Also, do not send it by the Coach, (it may appear ridiculous to you) but I would as soon loose a piece of my memory as it.— I feel it is of such consequence to my preserving a just recollection of the different places we visit."
By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
Caroline provided specific feedback on Charles Darwin's early diary entries. She noted that in the first part of his journal, Darwin seemed to have been influenced by Alexander von Humboldt, adopting a similar phraseology and occasionally using "flowery French expressions" instead of his own straightforward style. Caroline observed that this made Darwin's writing sound more poetic and less natural for him as an English writer. Despite these stylistic influences, she expressed overall appreciation for the journal, stating that she liked "the greatest part exceedingly" and found no fault with it.

Caroline's feedback reflects her perception of Darwin's writing style as initially being overly influenced by another author's language, which made it less direct and simple than his usual manner. However, she also recognized the value in his descriptions and overall content, indicating that despite these stylistic choices, the journal was still engaging and well-received. Her comments suggest an awareness of Darwin's potential to improve by returning to a more natural and straightforward style while maintaining the quality of his observations and reflections.

In April 1836, Captain FitzRoy proposed to Charles Darwin that they collaborate on publishing an account of their voyage. Specifically, FitzRoy suggested that he would take charge of arranging and disposing of Darwin's journal entries, integrating them with his own narrative for the publication. Darwin responded positively to this proposal, expressing his willingness to participate if FitzRoy believed that the details in Darwin's journal were valuable enough to be published. Darwin had already shared some parts of his journal with FitzRoy, who had read through them and expressed approval.

Darwin sought input from his family regarding FitzRoy's proposal but was mindful of naval customs, which typically granted the captain first rights to use any papers related to the voyage. This indicates that while Darwin was open to collaborating on the publication, he also recognized the authority and precedence given to FitzRoy as the ship's captain.

query: What were FitzRoy's concerns regarding Darwin's preface to volume III of their publication, and how was the issue resolved?
reference_contexts:
['== Publication of FitzRoy's narrative and Darwin's book ==
Darwin reorganised his diary, trimmed parts, and incorporated scientific material from his field notes. He passed his writing to the publisher Henry Colburn, and in August 1837 had the first proofs back from the printer. Henslow helped check them; on 4 November, Darwin wrote to him that "If I live till I am eighty years old I shall not cease to marvel at finding myself an author". Part of it was printed, "the smooth paper and clear type has a charming appearance, and I sat the other evening gazing in silent admiration at the first page of my own volume, when I received it from the printers!"
FitzRoy had to edit King's account of the first voyage, adding extracts from the journal of the previous captain of Beagle and his own journal when he took over, as well as write his own account of the second voyage. In mid-November 1837, he took offence that Darwin's preface to volume III (and a similar preface to the first part of The Zoology) lacked, in his view, enough acknowledgement of the help given by FitzRoy and other officers; the problem was overcome. By the end of February 1838, King's Narrative (volumes I) and Darwin's Journal (volume III) had been printed, but FitzRoy was still hard at work on volume II.
The Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839, as the Narrative of the Surveying Voyages of His Majesty's Ships Adventure and Beagle, describing their Examination of the Southern Shores of South America, and the Beagle's Circumnavigation of the Globe, in three volumes. Volume one covers the first voyage under Commander Phillip Parker King, volume two is FitzRoy's account of the second voyage. Darwin's Journal and Remarks, 1832–1835 forms the third volume, and the fourth volume is a lengthy appendix. The publication was reviewed as a whole by Basil Hall in the July 1839 issue of the Edinburgh Review. 
Volume two includes FitzRoy's Remarks with reference to the Deluge in which he recanted his earlier interest in the geological writings of Charles Lyell and his remarks to Darwin during the expedition that sedimentary features they saw "could never have been effected by a forty days' flood", asserting his renewed commitment to a literal reading of the Bible. He had married on the ship's return, and his wife was very religious.
Darwin's contribution proved remarkably popular and the publisher, Henry Colburn of London, announced on 15 August a separate volume of Darwin's text, published with a new title page as Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle. The Publishers‘ Circular of 2 September carried an advertisement for this volume, as well as a separate advertisement for the other volumes, as listed at William Broderip's article in the Quarterly Review. This was apparently done without seeking Darwin's permission or paying him a fee.']
reference_answer: FitzRoy had concerns about Darwin's preface to volume III because he felt it lacked sufficient acknowledgment of the help provided by himself and other officers. This lack of recognition offended FitzRoy. The issue was eventually overcome, although the specific details of how it was resolved are not provided in the context information. It is likely that some form of negotiation or amendment took place to address FitzRoy's concerns about proper credit being given for contributions made during their voyages.
